SENT.plain: Mesenteric venous thromboses are often associated with antithrombin III deficiency
We can suspect this clinical diagnosis in patients with nonspecific abdominal pain syndrome and personal or familial history of mesenteric venous thrombosis
We report the case of a 63-old-male caucasian with antithrombin III deficiency and rectal bleeding who was diagnosed with mesenteric venous thrombosis at exploratory laparotomy
This case emphasizes the necessity of a careful history in all patients without an obvious diagnosis
In this way, we can invoke the diagnosis of mesenteric venous thrombosis quickly and begin the heparin therapy while waiting for the results of further confirmatory tests
